L. with COX-2 inhibitory activity

document.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O

subSection.paragraph:
Hypericum monogynum
L.
Chemical constituents
Polycyclic polyprenylated acylphloroglucinols
Flavonoids
COX-2 inhibitors
A B S T R A C T

Hypericum monogynum
L. ( Hypericaceae ) has been used as a folk Chinese medicine for the treatment of inflammatory related diseases. Cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) is a crucial target for the development of agents to treat inflammation. To search for anti-inflammatory compounds from traditional Chinese medicines, a chemical constituent study along with COX-2 inhibitory activity analysis was performed for this plant. In this study, sixteen chemical monomers, including three undescribed oxidative degradation polycyclic polyprenylated acylphloroglucinols (PPAPs, hypemoins C–E), two undescribed PPAPs (hypemoins A and B), and 11 known compounds, were identified from the flowers of
H. monogynum
. Their structures were characterized by HRESIMS, NMR techniques, ECD, and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Four flavonoid derivatives showed remarkable COX-2 inhibitory activities, with IC 50 values ranging from 0.220 ± 0.006 to 1.655 ± 0.098 μM. Among these compounds, the possible recognition mechanism between quercetin 3-(6 ′′ -O-caffeoyl)-β-3-D-galactoside and COX-2 was predicted by molecular docking analysis. Moreover, the multidrug resistance reversal activities for the selected compounds were evaluated.

Hypericum monogynum
L. ( Hypericaceae ), a shrub, mainly grows in lowland provinces of China , such as Sichuan , Anhui , Fujian , Guangdong , Guangxi , Guizhou , Henan , Hubei , and Hunan ( Editorial Committee of Chinese Flora, 1990 ). This plant has been prescribed as a folk Chinese medicine for the treatment of hepatitis, conjunctivitis, acute laryngopharyngitis, and snake bites (Editorial committee of the administration bureau of traditional Chinese medicine, 1999). The occurrence and development of the diseases described above are closely related to inflammation ( Chen et al., 2020 ; Lee et al., 2012 ; Qin et al., 2020 ). Previous phytochemical investigations of this species have revealed that it is rich in different types of specialized metabolites including flavonoids, polycyclic polyprenylated acylphloroglucinols (PPAPs), diterpenes, and xanthones ( Xu et al., 2016 ; Zeng et al., 2018 , 2021a , 2021b ). Among these specialized metabolites, some xanthones and PPAPs have been shown to exhibit neuroprotective effects and multidrug resistance (MDR) reversal activities ( Xu et al., 2016 ; Zeng et al., 2021a ).

Thus, to explore the potential anti-inflammatory compounds from
H. monogynum
, subsequent chromatographic fractionation of the MeOH extract of the flowers of
H. monogynum
gave seven PPAPs ( 1–7 ), four flavonoids ( 8–11 ), and five phenolics ( 12–16 ). Among them, compounds 1–5 are undescribed compounds with a unique tricyclic γ -lactone moiety. All compounds were screened for their inhibitory effects on COX-2. Moreover, selected compounds were tested for multidrug resistance reversal activity. Herein, the isolation, structural elucidation, and bioactive study of these compounds are described.

document.paragraph: * Corresponding author. State Key Laboratory of Functions and Applications of Medicinal Plants, Guizhou Medical University, Guiyang, 550014, China .

** Corresponding author. The Key Laboratory of Chemistry for Natural Products of Guizhou Province and Chinese Academy of Sciences, Guiyang, 550014, China . E-mail addresses: yuanchunmao01@126.com (C.-M. Yuan), haoxj@mail.kib.ac.cn (X.-J. Hao).

subSection.paragraph: Hypemoin A ( 1 ), a white amorphous powder, presented a molecular formular of C 26 H 36 O 7 from the HR-ESI-MS ion at m / z 483.2346 [M + Na] + (calcd. for C 26 H 36 O 7 Na, 483.2353). The 1D NMR data ( Table 1 ) were similar to those of biyoulactone B ( 7 ) ( Tanaka et al., 2011 ). The planar structure for compound 1 with units A and B was readily assigned from 2D NMR spectroscopy ( Fig. 2 ). The difference between those two compounds was that a 2-methylbutanoyl group at C- 5 in 7 was replaced by a 2-methylpropanoyl group ( δ C 206.0, 37.9, 17.0, and 17.7) in 1 . This deduction was confirmed by the HMBC correlations of both H 3 -13 and H 3 -14 to C-11 and C-12 together with the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of H 3 -13/H-12/H 3 -14 ( Fig. 2 ). Other parts of 1 were identical to those of 7 by analysis of the 2D NMR spectroscopic data. The relative configuration of 1 was partially deduced by a NOESY experiment ( Fig. 2 ), in which cross-peaks of Me-27/H-19/H-22 β /Me-26 revealed that these groups were co-facial and were assigned as being in the β- orientation. In addition, NOESY correlations of 20-OH/H-23 revealed that these groups are α- oriented. Unfortunately, the relative configuration of 1 could not be determined due to the lack of key NOESY correlations. Luckily, crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction could be obtained from ethanol. X-ray diffraction analysis, conducted with Cu Kα radiation, not only confirmed the complete structure but also assigned the absolute configurations of all asymmetric carbon centers ( Fig. 3 ).

Hypemoin B ( 2 ) had the same molecular formula as compound 1 (C 26 H 36 O 7 ) by the HRESIMS ion at m / z 483.2347 [M +Na] + (calcd. for C 26 H 36 O 7 , 483.2353). Detailed analysis of the 1 H and 13 C NMR data ( Table 1 ) indicated that compound 2 had the same planar structure as compound 1 . The chemical shift of C-23 was shifted significantly upfield from δ C 47.4 in 1 to δ C 44.3 in 2 , which implied that compound 2 was a 23-epimer of compound 1 . In the NOESY spectrum ( Fig. 4 ), the correlations of 6-OH/H 3 -7, 6-OH/H-18β, H-18 β /H-19, H-19/H-23, and H-23/ H 3 -27 were readily observed, supporting the β -configuration of H-23. Moreover, the calculated electronic circular dichroism (ECD) curve matched well with the experimental ECD curve ( Zeng et al., 2021a ), confirming the absolute configuration of 2 ( Fig. 4 ). Thus, the structure of 2 was elucidated as shown ( Fig. 1 ).

Hypemoin C ( 3 ) was designated with the molecular formula C 20 H 30 O 4 (six degrees of unsaturation), as determined by HR-ESI-MS data at m/z 357.2033 [M + Na] + (calcd. for C 20 H 30 O 4 Na, 357.2036). Detailed comparison of its 1 H and 13 C NMR data ( Table 2 ) revealed that 3 shared the same moiety of unit B as that of compound 1 . This inference was confirmed by the multiple HMBC correlations as well as 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations, as shown in Fig. 5 . However, unit A was oxidized to a side chain of 2,5-dimethylhex-4-enoyl. The HMBC correlations ( Fig. 5 ) from H 2 -10 to C-13, from H 3 -15 to C-13 and C-14, and from both H 3 -19 and H 3 -20 to C-16 and C-18, together with the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of H-14/H 2 -16/H-17, supported the presence of this side chain (C-13‒C-20) connected at C-2. The NOESY cross-peaks of H-6α/OH-5, OH-5/H-8, H-8/H-3α, and H-8/H-10α implied the α- orientation of these groups. Moreover, the NOESY cross-peaks from Me-12 to H-6β and H-4 and from H-4 to H-3β led to the β- orientation assignment of these protons. In addition, the coupling constant for H-4 (td, J = 12.6, 5.1 Hz) indicated the trans-junction of the octahydroindene ring system ( Tanaka et al., 2011 ) ( Fig. 5 ). Thus, the relative configuration of this rare octahydro-1H-1,4-methanocyclopenta [c]oxepine ring system was assigned. Subsequently, the relative configuration of the side chain (2, 5-dimethylhex-4-enoyl) was fixed. However, the relative configuration of the methyl group of C-15 could not be assigned due to the lack of a key NOESY correlation of this group located on the side chain as well as the rotation of this side chain. The structure of 3 , as an undescribed oxidative degradation product of compounds 1 and 2 , was therefore elucidated and given the name hypemoin C ( 3 ).

caption.paragraph: 1 H (600 MHz) and 13 C (150 MHz) NMR data of 1 and 2 in DMSO‑ d .

subSection.paragraph: Compounds 4 and 5 presented molecular formulas of C 14 H 20 O 5 and C 12 H 18 O 3 deduced from their HR-ESI-MS ions at m/z 291.1201 [M + Na] + (calcd. for C 14 H 20 O 5 Na, 291.1203) and 233.1145 [M + Na] + (calcd. for C 12 H 18 O 3 Na, 233.1148), respectively. Comparison of the 1D NMR data of 4 and 5 with those of hypemoin C ( 3 ) suggested that the substituted group at C-2 was further oxidized to an ester ( 4 ) or degraded to a hydrogen atom ( 5 ). Further observation revealed that the ester group was located at C- 2 in 4 by the HMBC correlations of 14-OCH 3 ( δ H 3.69, s) to C-13 ( δ C 170.0). For compound 5 , the HSQC correlation from H-2 ( δ H 2.73, td, J = 4.9, 1.8 Hz) to C-2 ( δ C 40.9) and the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of H-2/H 2 -3 indicated that there was no substituent group at C-2. The same NOESY correlations and 1D NMR data between 4 and 3 assigned the same relative configurations ( Fig. 5 ). The absolute configuration of 4 (1 S , 4 S , 5 R , 8 R , 9 S ) was determined by ECD calculation ( Fig. 6 ) ( Zeng et al., 2021a ), which indicated that the experimental ECD results were consistent with the calculated ECD results. The well-matched experimental ECD spectra of 5 and 4 further confirmed the absolute configuration of 5 ( Fig. 6 ). Hence, the structures of 4 and 5 , as undescribed further oxidative degradation products of compound 3 , were established as shown in Fig. 1 . To the best of our knowledge, compounds 3–5 represent the first oxidative degradation PPAPs with an octahydro-1H-1,4-methanocyclopenta [c]oxepine ring system.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. Chemical structures of compounds of 1–16 .

subSection.paragraph:
H. monogynum
has been used as a folk Chinese medicine for the treatment of inflammatory related diseases, and COX-2 is a crucial target for the development of agents to treat inflammation. Therefore, we evaluated the in vitro anti-inflammatory properties of compounds 1–16 . The results ( Table 3 ) showed that flavonoids 8–11 showed significant inhibitory activity, with IC 50 values ranging from 0.220 ± 0.006 to 1.655 ± 0.098 μM ( Yan et al., 2019 ). Among them, flavonoids with substituted sugars ( 8 , 10 , and 11 ) were the best COX-2 inhibitors, with IC 50 values ranging from 0.220 ± 0.006 –0.265 μM. PPAP derivatives ( 1–7 ) and phenolics ( 12–16 ) showed no activity (IC 50 > 20 μM).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 3. X-ray crystallographic structure of 1 (displacement ellipsoids are drawn at the 30% probability level).

subSection.paragraph: To investigate the molecular recognition mechanism between the most active compound and COX-2, compound 8 was applied to in silico analysis with a human COX-2 protein model (PDB code: 5IKQ) ( Orlando and Malkowski, 2016 ; Qin et al., 2020 ). As shown in Fig. 7 , the results demonstrate that hydrogen bonds exist between 8 and residues in the hydrophobic channel, leading to the catalytic site of the protein. Specifically, five hydrogen bonds were observed to form between a carbonyl group of C-4 and TRP-387, between 4 ′′ -OH and HIS-214, between 6 ′′′ -OH and GLN-289, and between 7 ′′′ -OH and ASC-222. Moreover, the structure of 8 was packed into the hydrophobic pocket formed by GLN-203, LEU-291, TRP-387, and LYS-214, favoring binding. These interactions contribute to the localization of the inhibitor within the hydrophobic COX-2 channel ( Fig. 7 ).

Since many PPAP derivatives have been reported to possess moderate to significant MDR reversal activities ( Zeng et al., 2021a ; Zhang et al., 2020 ), compounds 1–7 and 9 (20 μM) along with adriamycin (ADR, 40 μM) were evaluated for their MDR reversal activity against MCF-7/ADR cells by the MTT method ( Table 4 ). Then, the active compounds ( 1 , 2 , 6 , and 7 ) were screened for their cytotoxicity against MCF-7/ADR cells, and no obvious cytotoxicity toward the tested cell lines was observed (IC 50 > 150 μM). The results showed that four PPAPs ( 1 , 2 , 6 , and 7 ) showed moderate reversal activity against MCF-7/ADR cells at a concentration of 20 μM, with reverse folds (RFs) ranging from 11 to 27 ( Table 4 ). When compounds 1 and 2 with a unit A fragment were oxidized to a side chain ( 3 ) or an ester ( 4 ) or degraded to a hydrogen atom ( 5 ), the activity disappeared.

Optical rotations were determined on a JASCOP-1020 polarimeter. UV spectra were detected on a Shimadzu UV-2401PC spectrometer. IR spectra were determined on a Bruker FT-IR Tensor-27 and iCAN 9 infrared spectrophotometer with KBr disks. 1 H NMR, 13 C NMR, and 2D NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance NEO 600 spectrometer using TMS as an internal standard. ESI-MS and HR-ESI-MS analysis were carried out on Agilent 1100 instrument and Thermo ultimate 3000/Q EXACTIVE FOCUS mass spectrometers, respectively. Column chromatography was performed on silica gel (300–400 mesh; Qingdao Marine Chemical Co. Ltd, China ), Sephadex LH-20 (40–70 μm, Amersham Pharmacia Biotech AB, Uppsala , Sweden ), and RP-C18 gel (40–63 μm, Merck, Darmstadt, Germany ). X-ray data were generated using a Bruker SMART APEX-II CCD diffractometer equipped. CD spectra were recorded with an Applied Photophysics Chirascan spectrometer. Semi-preparative HPLC was performed on an instrument consisting of a Hanbon NP7005c controller, a Hanbon NP7005 pump, and a Hanbon NU3000c UV detector with a YMC-Triart-C18 column (250 × 10.0 mm, 5 μm). Fractions were monitored by TLC (GF 254, Qingdao Marine Chemical Co, Ltd.), and spots were visualized by heating silica gel plates immersed in 5% H 2 SO
4 in
ethanol. All solvents used for general chromatography were analytical grade (Sinopharm Chemical Reagents Co. Ltd, China ), and the solvents used for HPLC were HPLC grade (Cinc High Purely Solvents, Shanghai , China ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 4. Key NOESY 2D NMR correlations and experimental and calculated ECD spectra of 2 .
1 H (600 MHz) and 13 C (150 MHz) NMR data of 3–5 in DMSO‑ d .
Fig. 5. Key 2D NMR correlations of compounds 3–5 .

subSection.paragraph:
The flowers of
Hypericum monogynum
L. ( Hypericaceae ) were collected from Guiyang, (GPS coordinates: 26 ◦ 11 ′ –
27 ◦ 22 ′ N
, 106 ◦ 07 ′ -
107 ◦ 17 ′ E
), Guizhou Province of China , in
June 2018
of dry season, and were authenticated by Dr. Wei Gu. A voucher specimen ( H20180601 ) has been deposited at the Key Laboratory of Chemistry for Natural Products of Guizhou Province and Chinese Academy of Sciences
.

The air-dried flowers of
H. monogynum
( 9 kg ) were extracted with 50 L MeOH at room temperature for 3 times (2 days for each time). The MeOH extract was concentrated by rotary evaporator to give 3 kg of crude residue, which was fractionated by silica gel chromatography eluted with petroleum ether (PE)/EtOAc (100:0 → 0:100, v/v) and then CHCl 3 /MeOH (90:10 → 0:100, v/v) to obtain seven major fractions (A–G). Fraction D ( 220 g ) was followed by RP-C18 chromatography column (CC) eluted with a MeOH/H 2 O gradient (4:6 → 10:0, v/v) to yield five subfractions (D1–D5). Fraction D2 ( 37 g ) was subjected on a silica gel column, eluted with PE/CHCl 3 (8:2, v/v) to give five subfractions (Fr. D2a‒Fr. D2e). Subsequently, Fr. D2d ( 6.8 g ) was separated on Sephadex LH-20 column (MeOH) to provide five subfractions (Fr. D2d1‒Fr. D2d5). Fr. D2d3 ( 180 mg ) was purified by semi-preparative HPLC separation (MeOH/H 2 O, 78:22, v/v, 2.0 mL/min) to obtain 1 (10.0 mg, tR = 38.5 min), 2 ( 9.8 mg , tR = 42.1 min), 6 (32.0 mg, tR = 47.2 min), and 7 (28.0 mg, tR =30.1 min). Fr. D2d4 ( 4.8 g ) was purified by silica gel CC (CHCl 3 ‒EtOAc, 90:10, v/v), followed by semi-preparative HPLC ( CH 3CN/H 2 O, 68:32, v/v, 2.0 mL/min) to give 3 (12.0 mg, tR =42.1 min), 4 ( 5.7 mg , tR =48.3 min), and 5 ( 9.8 mg , tR = 50.9 min). Fraction E ( 40 g ) was repeatedly chromatographed over silica gel column (CHCl 3 ‒EtOAc, 90:10, v/v) and Sephadex LH-20 column (MeOH) to give 12 ( 6 mg ), 13 ( 8 mg ), 14 ( 5 mg ), 15 ( 5 mg ), and 16 ( 32 mg ). The major component compound 9 ( 1 g ) was obtained from fraction F ( 180 g ), eluted with CHCl 3 /MeOH (20:1, v/v), on a silica gel column. After the removal of 9 , the residue of fraction F was chromatographed on a silica gel column (CHCl 3 –MeOH, 10:1, v/v) and further purified by HPLC (MeOH/H 2 O, 21:79, v/v, 2.0 mL/min) to yield 10 ( 31 mg , tR = 40.5 min) and 11 ( 25 mg , tR = 45.2 min). Fraction G ( 323 g ) was subjected on chromatographed over silica gel (CHCl 3 –MeOH, 6:1, v/v) to afford 8 ( 727 mg ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 7. Binding pose of compound 8 with COX-2.

document.paragraph: White amorphous powder; [ α ] 24 D +50 ( c 0.2, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 202 (4.29) nm; IR (KBr) v max 2971, 2937, 2869,1709, 1628, 1596, 1465, 1383, 1238, 1134, 1116, 982, 923, 818, 703, 534 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR and 13 C NMR data ( Table 1 ); HR-ESI-MS m/z 483.2347 ([M + Na] + , calcd for C 26 H 36 O 7 Na: 483.2353).

subSection.paragraph: Colorless oil; [ α ] 24 D +48 ( c 0.2, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 201 (2.91) nm; IR (KBr) v max 2969, 2931, 1769, 1708, 1457, 1380, 1304, 1229, 1129, 1039, 968, 914, 689 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR and 13 C NMR data ( Table 2 ); HR-ESI-MS m/z 357.2033 ([M +Na] + , calcd for C 20 H 30 O 4 Na: 357.2036).

Theoretical calculations of ECD spectra for compounds 2 and 4 were performed with the Gaussian 09 program package ( Zeng et al., 2021a ). The preliminary conformational distributions search was performed by HyperChem Release 8.0 software. Selected conformers with distributions higher than 1% were further optimized by the DFT (density functional theory) method at the B3LYP/6–311 +g (d) level in Gaussian 09 program package ( Zeng et al., 2021a ). The ECD of the conformer of selected conformers was then calculated by the TD-DFT method at the CAM-B3LYP/tzvp levels with the PCM model in methanol solution. The overall calculated ECD curves were weighted by Boltzmann distribution. The calculated ECD spectra were produced by SpecDis 1.604 ( Zeng et al., 2021a ). Detailed calculated parameters were proved in Supporting Information.

A suitable crystal of compound 1 was obtained by using the solvent vapor diffusion method. The single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were recorded on a Bruker D8 QUEST instrument (Cu K α radiation). Crystals were kept at 100 (2) K during data collection. The crystallographic data of those compounds in standard CIF format were deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. The data can be accessed free of charge at http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/.

Crystal data for 1 : C 26 H 36 O 7 •C 2 H 6 O, M =506.61, a =10.3256 (4) Å, b =8.9864 (4) Å, c =15.2412 (7) Å, α =90 ◦ , β =107.972 (2) ◦ , γ =90 ◦ , V =1345.23 (10) Å 3 , T =100 (2) K, space group P 1211, Z =2, μ (Cu Kα) = 0.740 mm 1 , 23,817 reflections measured, 5271 independent reflections (
Rint
=0.0572). The final
R 1
values were 0.0332 (
I >
2 σ ( I )). The final wR ( F 2 ) values were 0.0807 (
I >
2 σ ( I )). The final
R 1
values were 0.0356 (all data). The final wR ( F 2 ) values were 0.0830 (all data). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.053. Flack parameter = 0.02 (7). CCDC: 2,088,265.

Compounds were evaluated for COX-2 inhibitory activity in vitro by using cyclooxygenase 2 inhibitor screening kit (Beyotime Company, Shanghai , China ) ( Yan et al., 2019 ). COX-2 Assay Buffer, COX-2 Cofactor, and human recombinant COX-2 enzyme were pre-incubated with test compounds for 10 min at 37 ◦ C, and the COX-2 Probe was added. The reaction was started by the addition of COX-2 substrate and allowed to proceed for 5 min. The intensity of fluorescence was measured using a 560 nm excitation wavelength and a 590 nm emission wavelength using a micro plate reader (Thermo Varioskan LUX, Waltham, USA ). All the tests were repeated three times independently.
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

of Sciences for Chunmao Yuan (RZ [2020]82).
